THE HUDSON'S BAY HOUSE.

We have recently in these columns advanced the necessity of the immediate construction of a line of railway to Hudson's Bay, at Nelson or Churchill River (this latter being the shortest route), in order to Prince Albert, as the only and shortest way of affording a cheap outlet for the surplus products of the prairies to the West, to the markets of Europe. Any information on this subject may be sent to Mr. George A. Haynes, C. E., of Hartley Bay, who, Young, civil engineers, has furnished us with the following statement regarding the proposed Hudson's Bay Railway and its advantages:

Mr. Haynes says: It will be found very interesting in view of a renewal agitation for a railway to Hudson's Bay. Mr. Haynes explains the advantages of the route via Hudson's Bay, and the reasons why it should be adopted.

From Winnipeg to the Saskatchewan River at the northwestern corner of Lake Winnipeg, the level is about 700 feet above sea-level; no hills of any importance having to be surmounted. From the mouth of Red River to the Saskatchewan River, except along the banks of the lake as far north as Big Grindstone Point, is still mountainous. Some years ago the Canadian government surveyed this section of country as an Inland Route, but it has not been followed up by any extension of the railway from Winnipeg to the boundary of the prairie, owing to the lack of means of farming to agriculture. The soil is, however, good and well adapted for farming purposes, and a large portion of it is open for settlement. The distance from Winnipeg to Great Rapids on the Saskatchewan River is about 400 miles. The number of rivers to be crossed is comparatively small, being about five, with the exception of the two Saskatchewan, none of them large. For the corresponding distance from Winnipeg to Lake Superior, there are at least twenty-five streams which would have to be crossed, and a country traversed not fit for any other purpose than mining.

The strike still continues amongst the employees of the P. R. R., although the wages are now considerably higher. There seems to be little doubt that in this instance the employers are to blame, and that their demands are unreasonable. The wages, some of the engineers as high as $500 a month. The company proposes to pay the wages during the winter months, when the receipts of the road are comparatively small, and the amount of wages to be paid, would be placed under the control of the Superintendent of the Hudson's Bay Company, England, whose head quarters are somewhere in the United States. Superintendent Ryan has been appointed to take charge of a new agency, with his management, and to interview the employees. Mr. Ryan is a man of considerable tact, and the result always is that the employees have to give in, and submit to the demands made upon them by their superiors and families, and are obliged to the public for great inconvenience and loss. We hope that the P. R. R. company will yield the folly of their conduct, and return to their work.

O'Donnell, the brother of Carey, was hanged in London Dec. 1st, notwithstanding the strenuous exertions of the prisoner's friends. The prisoner was tried for murder, and was convicted. He had been charged with the murder of his brother, who had been killed by Carey, and never had been sorry for it. The prisoner's Conduct was generally approved by his friends, and he was thought to be innocent. The prisoner was tried in New York, and was given as his opinion, "I am innocent."

THE NORTH WEST.

A Settler's Trip Through the "Great Low Land" (the Plain) Near St. Boniface, in Manitoba.

Montreal star:

Mr. David Smith, who has just returned from a six weeks' journey in Manitoba and the North West, where he went with Colonists under the auspices of the Great Low Land, to inspect the lands of the Land and Colonization Company of Canada, states that he had a most delightful trip. The Great Low Land Company is on the North Saskatchewan river about 500 miles north-west of Winnipeg. They were the first settlers to go from Winnipeg as far as Qu'Appelle station, about 80 miles east of Regina, and then proceeded to Prince Albert, 275 miles, with the exception of one stage and took seven days in making the trip. They passed through the Qu'Appelle Valley, which is a beautiful country with rolling plains, and then the Touchwood Hills, a fairly wooded range, which they thought would be a good country for settlement. From thence they crossed the salt plains, a wide expanse of level land, which will eventually be rendered fit for settlement. The Valley of the Saskatchewan was their next object, which is reported to be a very fine farming country, and is already coming in. After crossing the South Saskatchewan into the Dust Lake district, they came to Prince Albert, many sections have been taken up. A drive of twenty miles through balsam spruce forest brought them to settlers at Prince Albert settlement, which is a distance of twenty-five miles, until the town is completed. The settlement is being estimated that from five to six thousand people are here located,—many of whom have been there several years, and now possess good substantial houses, barns, built with lumber at Prince Albert. They appeared to be in comfortable condition. The town of Prince Albert, which is situated on the south side of the North Saskatchewan River, is a flourishing place, with a population of about twelve hundred. It has two grain mills, two saw mills, flouring mill, lumber yard, planing mills, brickyard, several general stores, three churches, a college and school, and a hospital. It is a large town, situated, as it is, in the centre of a very large tract of fine farming country, which will soon be in railway communication, as the Macdonald and Northwestern Railway, which starts from Portage la Prairie on the C. P. R., and runs thirty-eight miles, will have been built, is expected to reach there in about two years and the Government has just purchased the right-of-way, which will prove a great convenience.

At Prince Albert, teams and an outfit for camping were obtained, and some funds sent by Mr. Smith to assist him in that place, the tract of land which Messrs. Smith and Butler went to was reached by oxen teams, as there is no Canadian Pacific Railway. They found the place well wooded, with plenty of water, and fully up to the requirements of a settlement, the soil being well suited for farming and grazing purposes. After spending some days on the land, Col. Butler wrote to Edmonston, who was going to Calgary, and he took the C. P. R. back to Winnipeg.

COMPLAINTS OF SETTLERS AGAINST THE GOVERNMENT.

Mr. Smith being asked by a Star reporter if he had found anything of the dissatisfaction amongst which so much has been written, and which has been said in some places people were complaining that the Government had not yet given them the parcels of land promised them, in matters which required, time, as it was necessary that responsible agents receive quarters since investigations were made. Mr. Smith stated that a settler had taken land previous to a land office being established in the locality, and was therefore unable to get his title. He also says that three years after making his entry the settler shall receive his title. These particular cases that have been completed their three years' residence on the land and are entitled to their patents. There are other cases, however, where the feeling amongst the Government should open the mile belt, that is, the land reserved on each side of the railway, for the use of the colonists. At present, however, they are permitted to locate on Government sections within the mile belt.

With respect to the dissatisfaction which exists on account of the high duties on agricultural implements imported from England, Mr. Smith, of the North West, Mr. Smith is of the opinion that can be easily disposed of by the Government negotiating reasonable terms to investigate the claims of settlers, and give them their lands immediately. This would then enable the settler to move on, occupy his land, and obtain more land for that purpose, which he is now unable to do without having a valid title, known fact, but that might be in the possession or involved in litigation.

THE COAL RESERVES.

Great excitement prevails in regard to the opening up of the extensive coal districts, which will reduce the price of fuel and solve a serious problem in localities where wood is scarce. Mr. Smith states that his trip was very pleasant, both the roads and the weather having been exceedingly fine.

COL BUTLER.

Notes on His Visit to the Great Land.

An Interesting Account of the Distinctive Author's Impressions and Opinions Regarding the Country.

The following is an extract from a letter written by Mr. Butler, who recently visited Prince Albert, in which he describes the climate, the soil, and the possibilities of the region:

"The opinion I then formed," said Col. Butler, "was to the effect that the land was not suitable for settlement. Since then, however, I have been convinced. These remarks refer particularly to the northern part of the region which has not yet been opened up. I believe that the soil is not suitable for cultivation, and that the climate is too severe for human habitation."

"I consider that the absence of rail communication with the rest of Canada is a serious drawback to the settlement of the region. While I was there before, I came across a number of settlers who had brought their families and stores home extending in scattered places over a distance of several miles. Edmonton is making progress, but I do not consider it as well situated as the settlements further north of the railroad. The Prince Albert settlement, generally speaking, has proved successful, and I believe that the people there are doing well."
